items.text: I frequently think about what could go wrong before making a decision.
items.rationale: Vigilance toward potential negative outcomes is a hallmark of prevention focus orientation.

items.text: My primary goal in life is to feel safe and secure.
items.rationale: Prioritizing safety and security reflects the core need-for-security dimension of prevention focus.

items.text: I would rather avoid a loss than pursue a potential gain.
items.rationale: Loss aversion over gain-seeking is the defining asymmetry of prevention-focused self-regulation.

items.text: I am careful to fulfill all of my duties and obligations.
items.rationale: Emphasis on duties and obligations reflects the ought-self guidance central to prevention focus.

items.text: When I consider a new opportunity, the first thing I think about is what I might lose.
items.rationale: Framing opportunities in terms of potential losses is characteristic of prevention-focused cognition.

items.text: I tend to play it safe even when a riskier option might pay off more.
items.rationale: Conservative, risk-averse strategy selection is a behavioral signature of prevention focus.

items.text: People who know me would say I am cautious and careful in how I approach life.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of cautiousness maps directly to prevention-focused behavioral tendencies.

items.text: I worry about not meeting the expectations that others have of me.
items.rationale: Concern about failing to meet others' expectations reflects ought-self discrepancy anxiety central to prevention focus.

items.text: I double-check my work to make sure I haven't made any mistakes.
items.rationale: Error-detection and vigilance strategies are core self-regulatory behaviors of prevention focus.

items.text: I feel most relieved when I successfully avoid a negative outcome.
items.rationale: Experiencing relief (rather than joy) upon success is the characteristic emotional signature of prevention focus.

items.text: Rules and regulations exist for good reasons, and I make a point to follow them.
items.rationale: Valuing and adhering to rules reflects the ought-based, responsibility-driven nature of prevention focus.

items.text: I often imagine worst-case scenarios so I can prepare for them.
items.rationale: Defensive pessimism and anticipatory threat processing are cognitive strategies aligned with prevention focus.

items.text: I sometimes hold back from trying new things because I'm not sure they'll work out.
items.rationale: Hesitation toward novelty is consistent with prevention focus, but could also reflect low self-efficacy or trait anxiety more broadly.

items.text: I prefer sticking with what I know rather than experimenting with unfamiliar approaches.
items.rationale: Preference for the familiar aligns with prevention focus, though it could also reflect low openness to experience as a personality trait.

items.text: I set high standards for myself and feel terrible when I fall short of them.
items.rationale: High standards could reflect prevention focus (avoiding failure relative to ought-self) or promotion focus (striving toward ideal-self aspirations). The distress at falling short tips toward prevention, but the item is genuinely ambiguous.

items.text: I am energized by thinking about what I could achieve in the future.
items.rationale: Eagerness and energization from envisioning future accomplishments is a core feature of promotion focus.

items.text: I actively seek out opportunities for growth and advancement.
items.rationale: Approach-oriented pursuit of advancement and growth directly reflects promotion-focused self-regulation.

items.text: My decisions are usually guided by my hopes and aspirations rather than my fears.
items.rationale: Ideal-self guidance (hopes and aspirations) versus ought-self guidance (fears) is the defining distinction of promotion focus.

items.text: I feel happiest when I accomplish something I've been striving toward.
items.rationale: Experiencing cheerfulness and happiness upon goal attainment is the characteristic emotional signature of promotion focus.

items.text: I am willing to take risks if there is a chance of a big reward.
items.rationale: Risk tolerance in pursuit of gains reflects the eager, approach-oriented strategy of promotion focus.

items.text: When I see a chance to get ahead, I go for it without hesitating.
items.rationale: Seizing opportunities with eagerness and minimal hesitation is a behavioral hallmark of promotion-focused individuals.

items.text: I spend a lot of time daydreaming about the person I want to become.
items.rationale: Ideal-self elaboration and aspirational thinking are cognitive processes central to promotion focus.

items.text: People describe me as ambitious and driven.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of ambition and drive maps to the gain-seeking, advancement-oriented nature of promotion focus.

items.text: I focus more on what I can gain from a situation than on what I might lose.
items.rationale: Gain-framing over loss-framing is the defining cognitive orientation of promotion focus.

items.text: I feel dejected and disappointed when I miss out on an opportunity for success.
items.rationale: Dejection-related emotions (sadness, disappointment) upon failure are the specific emotional response pattern of promotion focus, distinct from agitation in prevention focus.

items.text: I believe that not trying is worse than trying and failing.
items.rationale: Valuing attempt over inaction reflects the errors-of-omission sensitivity characteristic of promotion focus.

items.text: I like to think about all the exciting possibilities that lie ahead of me.
items.rationale: Excitement about future possibilities reflects the approach motivation and ideal-self orientation of promotion focus.

items.text: I push myself hard to be the best version of myself.
items.rationale: Self-improvement striving is consistent with promotion focus, but 'pushing hard' could also reflect prevention-focused obligation to meet standards.

items.text: I tend to think about how my choices today will shape my future success.
items.rationale: Future-oriented thinking about success aligns with promotion focus, though strategic planning about consequences could also serve prevention-focused vigilance.

items.text: I am very persistent and refuse to give up on my goals, even when things get difficult.
items.rationale: Persistence could reflect promotion-focused eagerness to attain desired end-states, but it could equally reflect prevention-focused determination not to fail at one's obligations.
